Paderewski Vineyard:

Travel just west of Paso Robles, and you will find Paderewski Vineyard: 67 acres of undulating, steep, limestone rich hillsides within 570 rural, spring-fed acres. In the early 1900’s, this vineyard was cherished and farmed by world-renowned pianist, Polish diplomat, and vintner, Ignacy Jan Paderewski. Fast forward a century, and this property stood forgotten and fallow. Lucky for us, in 2004, we became the stewards of this amazing piece of property.

Planted: 2004 Acreage: 95 under vine, 570 total Soils: limestone, calcareous, rocky pH: low to mid 8 AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvedre, Petite Sirah, Syrah, Tempranillo, and Zinfandel White Varietals: Grenache Blanc, Picpoul Blanc, and Viognier

Catapult Vineyard:

Directly in the heart of the Paso Robles’ Templeton Gap, near the acclaimed L’Aventure and Booker Vineyards, sits our Catapult Vineyard. In 2008 we came across 45 barren acres of extreme rocky soils packed with silicious shale and little limestone content. Just the type of soils we love; soils that encourage the vines to struggle while finding nourishment deep within the ground. The reward of this hardworking vine are berries packed with wicked complexity and intense flavors.

Though barely three miles from our Paderewski Vineyard, the pH level at Catapult Vineyard is in the high 5’s. A nice complement to the dirt over at “Rewski”. This pH difference, coupled with the cooler mesoclimate at Catapult allows for different flavor profiles from the fruit produced.

Planted: 2008 Acreage: 28 under vine, 45 total Soils: shale, clay, silt, rocky pH: high 5s AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvèdre, Syrah, and Tempranillo White Varietals: Grenache Blanc,Roussane, and Viognier
palate: The 2016 Tempranillo is our unabashed Spanish cowboy, so different in flavor and structure from our other wines. It’s built to stand the test of time and needs a healthy decant or aging in your cellar to realize its true potential. Red plum, red cherry and sweet earth round the front upper and lower palate. A bright acidity and varietally-correct structure direct the wine to the back palate. From there, it’s a wild ride of texture shooting off in all directions. Dried tobacco leaf, fig, brown baking spice, vanilla and a hint of cedar linger on the finish.

palate: Whether you are Tempranillo fan or not, this Spaniard will have you by the heartstrings.  Epoch’s 2014 Tempranillo is so well rounded, so delicious while still staying true to the flavors and textures of the Tempranillo grape.  A consistent round of tannins stuff the mouth and keep the wine turning from front to back, filling your palate with dried cherries, red plum, Christmas and barrel spices, smoked and cured meats and sweet tobacco.  Minerality and bright acidity keep the wine from ever seeming too overpowering.  Big tannin in balance seems like an oxymoron but not in this bottle!

Planted: 2004 Acreage: 95 under vine, 570 total Soils: limestone, calcareous, rocky pH: low to mid 8 AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvedre, Petite Sirah, Syrah, Tempranillo, and Zinfandel White Varietals: Grenache Blanc, Picpoul Blanc, and Viognier
palate: With Don Juan suavity, our Tempranillo never lets us forget its Spanish roots. Tempranillo is on its own time, and regardless of vintage, it is always very different than our other varieties. We embrace its uniqueness and let it hang out in barrel and/or bottle for as long as is needed. The coolness of the ’11 vintage is apparent in the brightness of fruit and acid in this wine as well as its tight tannin structure. It begs for decanting (or drinking over a day or two), and then the true romantic emerges. Always connected to the earth, red plum, violet, forest floor, black olive and cigar box flavors converge into a Tempranillo form of elegance.

Paderewski Vineyard:

Travel just west of Paso Robles, and you will find Paderewski Vineyard: 67 acres of undulating, steep, limestone rich hillsides within 570 rural, spring-fed acres. In the early 1900’s, this vineyard was cherished and farmed by world-renowned pianist, Polish diplomat, and vintner, Ignacy Jan Paderewski. Fast forward a century, and this property stood forgotten and fallow. Lucky for us, in 2004, we became the stewards of this amazing piece of property.

Planted: 2004 Acreage: 95 under vine, 570 total Soils: limestone, calcareous, rocky pH: low to mid 8 AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvedre, Petite Sirah, Syrah, Tempranillo, and Zinfandel White Varietals: Grenache Blanc, Picpoul Blanc, and Viognier
palate: A traditional-styled wine for the passionate Rioja lover. As with many Rioja wines, our 2007 Tempranillo patiently aged in French oak barrels (23 months!) waiting for flavors and tannins to co-mingle perfectly. True to its variety, this wine plays on the senses differently than our other wines, yielding a new and exciting tasting experience. This wine presents smoky red cherry, red plum, leather and brown tea leaf flavors with a nutty, caramelized, refined and textured palate, indicative of its prolonged barrel age.

In the early 1900’s, this vineyard was cherished and farmed by world-renowned pianist, Polish diplomat, and vintner, Ignacy Jan Paderewski. Planted: 2004 Acreage: 95 under vine, 570 total Soils: limestone, calcareous, rocky pH: low to mid 8 AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvedre, Petite Sirah, Syrah, Tempranillo, and Zinfandel White Varietals: Grenache Blanc, Picpoul Blanc, and Viognier
palate: He didn’t go to prep school nor did any of his relatives go to college. He’s the first college grad of his family and from an Ivy League school no less. The 2013 Zinfandel is an inspirational story – where he’s from (the wrong side of the tracks), where he is now and his potential for the future. With no hoity-toity shoes to fill, he is defining what it means to be a Zinfandel and setting a new bar for what Zins can be – boisterous, charismatic and just down right irresistible aromatically, yet complex, layered and crying for cellar age on the palate. Who knows, he might be seen at dinner in the White House one day. He is a true example of the American Dream.

growingConditions:
Parentage: 100% York Mountain Vineyard 

The York Family, Paso wine pioneers and owners of this historic property for more than eighty years, planted vines on this land in 1882, making it one of the first vineyards on the central coast. Despite five name changes, prohibition, and the catastrophic San Simeon Earthquake, York Mountain Winery ran continuously for 119 years, making it one of the longest continuously run wineries in the United States. When we purchased the property in 2010, the site of the York family’s original vineyard was fallow, but we were eager to one day plants vines on these historic soils again.

 

In the spring of 2015, after much dreaming and planning, we began planting vines at this “cool climate” site (colder than Burgundy). Located just seven miles from the Pacific Ocean at an elevation of 1,500 feet, this property falls in the small 640 acre York Mountain AVA, which is outside of the very large Paso Robles AVA.

 

The soils and climate are very different than our other two vineyards. The combination of sandstone soils (some areas look like you are on the beach) with a very moderate climate due to the even closer proximity to the Pacific Ocean make this site quite the departure from our Paderewski and Catapult Vineyards. Because of its elevation and distance from the ocean, York Mountain receives more than twice the amount of rainfall as our other vineyards and has characteristic foggy mornings throughout the year with cool breezes all day long.

 

When deciding what to plant, we wanted to keep with what we know and love best, but we also decided to experiment a bit too. We planted mostly Syrah and Grenache with the hopes of crafting pure varietal expressions of these two Rhône grapes on our very different terroir. In addition, we grow a small amount of Viognier, Roussanne, Zinfandel, and for the first time ever, Cabernet. We love the spice, fresh fruit, and bright acidity York Mountain Vineyard brings out in these varieties.

description: The York Family, Paso wine pioneers and owners of this historic property for more than eighty years, planted vines on this land in 1882, making it one of the first vineyards on the central coast.

growingConditions:
Parentage: 56% Catapult and 44% Paderewski Vineyards

Stomping Grounds: Shale and limestone-studded hillsides of all exposures

Paderewski Vineyard:

Travel just west of Paso Robles, and you will find Paderewski Vineyard: 67 acres of undulating, steep, limestone rich hillsides within 570 rural, spring-fed acres. In the early 1900’s, this vineyard was cherished and farmed by world-renowned pianist, Polish diplomat, and vintner, Ignacy Jan Paderewski. Fast forward a century, and this property stood forgotten and fallow. Lucky for us, in 2004, we became the stewards of this amazing piece of property.

Planted: 2004 Acreage: 95 under vine, 570 total Soils: limestone, calcareous, rocky pH: low to mid 8 AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvedre, Petite Sirah, Syrah, Tempranillo, and Zinfandel White Varietals: Grenache Blanc, Picpoul Blanc, and Viognier

Catapult Vineyard:

Directly in the heart of the Paso Robles’ Templeton Gap, near the acclaimed L’Aventure and Booker Vineyards, sits our Catapult Vineyard. In 2008 we came across 45 barren acres of extreme rocky soils packed with silicious shale and little limestone content. Just the type of soils we love; soils that encourage the vines to struggle while finding nourishment deep within the ground. The reward of this hardworking vine are berries packed with wicked complexity and intense flavors.

Though barely three miles from our Paderewski Vineyard, the pH level at Catapult Vineyard is in the high 5’s. A nice complement to the dirt over at “Rewski”. This pH difference, coupled with the cooler mesoclimate at Catapult allows for different flavor profiles from the fruit produced.

Planted: 2008 Acreage: 28 under vine, 45 total Soils: shale, clay, silt, rocky pH: high 5s AVA: Paso Robles District: Willow Creek Red Varietals: Grenache, Mourvèdre, Syrah, and Tempranillo White Varietals: Grenache Blanc,Roussane, and Viognier
palate: This extended age version of our 2020 Epoch White is the same blend as our earlier bottling, just aged a bit longer in French oak foudre, and thus boasts a weightier palate with more umph.  The extra aging gifts us a seriously complex and layered wine with exuberant and inviting flavors of green mango, grilled pineapple, yellow peach, wet gravel, vanilla bean, honey, and brioche toast.  The palate is lush and round with flavors evenly flowing between fruit, minerals, and oak, and ending with a slight up-tick in texture on the back palate, which corsets all the complex character into a gorgeous, long finish.
name: White Extended Age
description: The extended age version of our Epoch White is aged a bit longer in French oak foudre, and thus boasts a weightier palate with more umph.

growingConditions:
In 2019, exceptional winter rainfall gave us a full soil moisture profiles and 
budburst occurred on par with long-term averages with very solid early shoot growth. Mid December through to the early March was extremely dry with virtually no rainfall. The mild days and cool nights in late February and early March aided in the final ripen creating strong varietal characters and crisp natural acids.

bottling: Bottled April 4 2022
growingConditions: Good winter rainfall meant near full soil moisture profiles at budburst. Moderate rain during early spring encouraged good shoot growth, with a quick and even flowering resulting in excellent fruit set.  Mild & dry conditions, without any significant extremes continued throughout the growing season.  Production levels were excellent, above long term averages and the mild & slow ripening conditions enabled strong varietal character to develop.  Vintage was dry and the weather stable so fruit was harvested, at optimal flavour development and high natural acidity.
nose: Floral, fragrant flowers and lemon pith with bright aromatics.
pairing: Lobster, crab, scallops, creamy pasta, roast chicken, corn or a cheese board
palate: A beautifully fresh and captivating wine. Searing acidity, slight butter/ popcorn malo notes with minerality, crunchy salivating acid.
name: Family Selection Single Vineyard Chardonnay
description: Medium gold, stone fruit and citrus blossom. White peach and citrus with a hint of brioche, good weight and mouthfeel. An elegant wine. Vegan Friendly.

aging: Free run juice taken and placed directly into new & seasoned French Oak barrels.  Indigenous yeast ferment, matured for 12 months
bottling: Bottled January 2022
growingConditions: The 2020 growing season was extremely dry season with a record temperature of 47 degrees recorded pre-Christmas.  Unfortunately this had a effect detrimental on yields so the production levels were quite low across the entire region.  The weather conditions were significantly improved during the ripening period - cooler and milder conditions allowed delicate flavours to develop.
nose: Stone peach, yellow grapefruit and honey suckle linger with integrated vanilla stick, toastiness and savoury flint presenting a great deal of depth and complexity.
pairing: Family Selection Chard pairs with lobster, crab, scallops, creamy pasta, roast chicken, corn on the cob and a cheese board
palate: Highlights of whipped lemon with honeydew melon and stone fruits are displayed on the mid palate followed by a luscious, creamy texture. A lovely play between fruit characters and winemaking influences. Extremely complex, layered and overall seamless.
name: Family Selection Single Vineyard Chardonnay
description: Medium gold, stone fruit and citrus blossom. White peach and citrus with a hint of brioche, good weight and mouthfeel. An elegant wine. Vegan Friendly.

pairing: Pan seared scallops and creamy pasta

pairing: Family Selection Chard pairs with lobster, crab, scallops, creamy pasta, roast chicken, corn on the cob and a cheese board

Full bodied with good weight and mouthfeel, 
the palate is long and well balanced. 
Refreshing with dry finish, the richness has firm acidity and oak complexity.

description:
A reserved style, soft with oak and fruit and has some great acidity.

White peach, zesty citrus with some flinty notes. 

Think Chablis in style. Clean and refreshing.

aging: predominately tank with a small amount of seasoned french oak for texture
bottling: Bottled December 15th, 2020
growingConditions:
In 2018, good winter rainfall and a warm October led to strong canopy growth 
and good fruit set. A frost event in November was a little scary and reduced yields in some areas. Warm and dry January/February weather enabled the fruit to intensify in flavour whilst retaining wonderfully fresh, natural acidity.

pairing: Fresh seafood and chicken. Chardonnay Single Vineyard pairs best with bright and clean flavoured dishes such as Oysters, Goat Cheese, Cauliflower Soup, Smoked Trout, Pork Tenderloin, white fish and Sushi.
palate: Subtle stone fruit, citrus with flinty notes. Clean and fresh

aging: 16 months
appearance: Light golden in colour with a straw tinge.
bottling: Bottled May 2 2016
growingConditions: Autumn and winter were dry and cool with low rainfall. White wines are looking solid this season showing lovely varietal flavours, backed by crisp natural acidity.
nose: Ripe stone fruit on the nose.

aging: 34 mths in new & seasoned French Oak hogsheads.
bottling: April 2022
growingConditions:
In 2019, exceptional winter rainfall gave us a full soil moisture profiles and 
budburst occurred on par with long-term averages with very solid early shoot growth. Mid-December through to the early March was extremely dry with virtually no rainfall. The mild days and cool nights in late February and early March aided in the final ripen creating strong varietal characters and crisp natural acids.
nose: Dried fruits, charry oak and vanilla with layers of complexity.
pairing: Grilled meats and vegetables, duck, braised dishes and hard cheeses
palate: Oaky highlights, mulberry red fruits and white pepper. Rich-medium full bodied, structural tannins, bold, chocolate and dried florals.
name: Single Vineyard Wrattonbully Cabernet Shiraz
description: Created from a blend of nearly equal proportions from the best sections the vineyard. This wine is consistently a real crowd pleaser. With the Shiraz making it instantly appealing in the Cabernet filling in the palate the result is a beautifully balanced quintessential Australian red blend.

aging: 26 months in new & seasoned oak barrels
bottling: Bottled in 2018
growingConditions: 2016 was a standout vintage. The characteristics of our Cabernet and our Shiraz that year were perfect to create our popular signature red blend, a classic Australian Cab Shiraz. Autumn and winter were dry and cool which meant the start of the growing season was slightly delayed. Rainfall was low. Irrigation was used to replenish soil moisture. Relatively mild summer climatic conditions - warm days and cool nights with an absence of extreme heat - ensured the fruit was able to ripen evenly and the flavours intensify.
nose: Dark berry with a hint of spice
pairing: Cabernet Shiraz pairs well with grilled meats and vegetables, duck, braised dishes, and hard cheeses. Roast lamb and veggies
palate: Blackcurrant, plums and berries with fine tannins and a long finish
name: Single Vineyard Wrattonbully Cabernet Shiraz
description: Created from a blend of nearly equal proportions from the best sections the vineyard. This wine is consistently a real crowd pleaser. With the Shiraz making it instantly appealing in the Cabernet filling in the palate the result is a beautifully balanced quintessential Australian red blend.

aging:
36 months in French and American
hogheads
bottling: bottled July 2018
growingConditions: With near average winter rainfall and warm early spring temperatures, budburst was early which had us on nervous frost duty.  Flowering was quick with good set. Mild weather during the day and cooler nights in February - March resulted in excellent slow ripening conditions for the fruit, preserving the flavour and natural acid.
nose: Balanced red and blackberry fruit notes with a hint of charred oak
pairing: Cabernet Shiraz pairs well with grilled meats and vegetables, duck, braised dishes and hard cheeses
palate:
Plums and berries fill the palate with 
fine tannins and a long finish.
name: Single Vineyard Wrattonbully Cabernet Shiraz
description: Created from a blend of nearly equal proportions from the best sections the vineyard. This wine is consistently a real crowd pleaser. With the Shiraz making it instantly appealing in the Cabernet filling in the palate the result is a beautifully balanced quintessential Australian red blend.

aging: Aged in hogshead oak barrels for 36 months
growingConditions: Near average winter rain and warm early spring heat meant budburst was early.  Cooler mid and late spring temperature slowed the growth and gave us some nervous nights on frost alert.  The heat returned in November with quick flowering and good set. The warm days and cool nights of summer gave us Cabernet with intense cassis and red berry flavour and Shiraz showed ripe plum and dark fruits. Both varietals gave us great colour intensity and structure.
nose: Soft blackcurrant and plum fruit notes have an abundant texture with rounded fine-grained tannins
pairing: Cabernet Shiraz pairs well with grilled meats and vegetables, duck, braised dishes and hard cheeses. Wagyu beef teppanyaki and vegetables
palate: With bottle age, the wines maturity shows cedar and chocolate complexity
name: Single Vineyard Wrattonbully Cabernet Shiraz
description: Created from a blend of nearly equal proportions from the best sections the vineyard. This wine is consistently a real crowd pleaser. With the Shiraz making it instantly appealing in the Cabernet filling in the palate the result is a beautifully balanced quintessential Australian red blend.

aging: 34 mths in new & seasoned French Oak hogsheads.
bottling: Bottled April 5 2022
growingConditions:
In 2019, exceptional winter rainfall gave us a full soil moisture profiles and 
budburst occurred on par with long term averages with very solid early shoot growth. Mid December through to the early March was extremely dry with virtually no rainfall. The mild days and cool nights in late February and early March aided in the final ripen creating strong varietal characters and crisp natural acids.
nose: Lifted dark cherries and blue fruits with undertones of stewed fruits, mulberry and satsuma plum balance a top charry French oak.
pairing: Pair with good friends or family. Also goes fabulously well with anything that comes off a BBQ or a hearty stew.
palate: Medium to full palate weight, powerful flavours of spice, pepper and sumac. Structural powdery tannins provide a dry finish to compliment the dark fruits.
name: Family Selection Single Vineyard Shiraz
description: Carefully selected from the best sections of our vineyard, the grapes are fermented in open top concrete fermentors then aged in a combination of new and seasoned French oak hogshead's for 24-34 months before bottling.  With minimal intervention to let the quality of the vintage shine. The resulting wine is elegant, refined and well balanced.

aging: 26 months in new & seasoned French Oak hogsheads.
bottling: Bottled June 5, 2018
growingConditions: 2016 was a standout vintage for Shiraz. The fruit was particularly intense in colour and flavour, as showcased in this Family Selection, single varietal Shiraz. Autumn and winter were dry and cool which meant the start of the growing season was slightly delayed. Winter rainfall was low and some irrigation was used to replenish the soil moisture. Relatively mild summer climatic conditions with warm days and cool nights. An absence of extreme heat ensured even ripening therefore intensifying the varietal characteristics.
nose: Rich blackberry, cedar and vanilla with a hint of spice
pairing: Juicy eye fillet steak
palate: Velvety smooth with ripe berry fruits and polished tannins. A hint of chocolate
name: Family Selection Single Vineyard Shiraz
description: Carefully selected from the best sections of our vineyard, the grapes are fermented in open top concrete fermentors then aged in a combination of new and seasoned French oak hogshead's for 24-34 months before bottling.  With minimal intervention to let the quality of the vintage shine. The resulting wine is elegant, refined and well balanced.

aging: The older wines were aged in French oak hogsheads for 2-3 years.
growingConditions: Various seasons
nose: Plums, cherries and spicy fruitcake notes
pairing:
Pavlova, pizza or curry! 
Sparkling Shiraz goes with pretty much anything, especially Christmas!
palate:
Spicy cherry sauce and fruitcake balance well-rounded tannins and brisk acidity. 
Lusciously full, and juicy with a hint of oak complexity deliver an intense, lingering finish.
name: Sparkling Shiraz
description: With a bright purple foam and a fine bead this wine is light in style and refreshing. Lush berry fruit with Christmas cake spice and some oak complexity.

name: Cabernet Sauvignon, Oakville
description: Our Oakville Cabernet Sauvignon shows impressive depth, richness and refinement on the palate. Generous black fruit flavors are accented by hints of dried herb, mocha and cedar against a backdrop of plush tannins. The bold flavors or an aged sirloin or roast rack of lamb pair well with this quintessential Oakville Cabernet Sauvignon.

name: Viognier, Paso Robles
description: Aromatically complex with citrus and honeysuckle notes on the nose and a plush feel on the palate, our Viognier consistently displays a fine balance of neutral acidity and intense concentration. This quintessential food wine was whole cluster pressed and stainless steel fermented to allow the vibrant, tropical and stone fruit characteristics of this varietal to shine.

name: Emily's Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Emily’s is our eponymous offering in remembrance of Emily Miner, co-founder of Miner Family Winery. This blend is as expressive and elegant as our muse. We honor her by crafting a decadent and rich wine layered with aromas of black fruit and hints of mocha, espresso and toasted oak. Truly iconic Napa Valley for a truly iconic woman.

name: Emily's Cabernet Sauvignon
description: Emily’s is our eponymous offering in remembrance of Emily Miner, co-founder of Miner Family Winery. This blend is as expressive and elegant as our muse. We honor her by crafting a decadent and rich wine layered with aromas of black fruit and hints of mocha, espresso and toasted oak. Truly iconic Napa Valley for a truly iconic woman.

name: Sauvignon Blanc, Napa Valley
description: This crisp Napa Valley Sauvignon Blanc is fermented and aged in stainless steel. With aromas of stone fruit and freshly cut herbs followed by grapefruit-melon flavors on the palate, this wine is best enjoyed in its youth.

name: The Oracle, Napa Valley Red Wine
description: Our flagship wine, a full-bodied, single vineyard red blend, grants a nod toward elegance. This Bordeaux-style blend is silky, reserved and supremely balanced. Lush aromatics of raspberry and dark cherry with a hint of eucalyptus, The Oracle is decadent, but with finesse. Earthiness and layers of dried flowers and cocoa integrate harmoniously into a finely balanced marriage between tannin and acid, providing the structure that ensures, like all impeccable beauties, this wine is sure to age gracefully.
